title: Quantiles and Percentiles: Understanding Data Distribution
contentHtml:
Quantiles and percentiles are fundamental concepts in descriptive statistics that help us understand the distribution of data.

A quantile is a value that divides the dataset into equal parts, while a percentile is a specific percentage point below which a certain percentage of values fall. For instance, the 25th percentile (Q1) is the median of the lower half of the data, and the 75th percentile (Q3) is the median of the upper half.
intuition: Think of quantiles as 'dividing lines' that help us understand the shape of the data distribution. They provide a more detailed view than just looking at the mean or median.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, understanding the distribution of data is crucial for model performance and robustness.

title: Quantiles and Percentiles: Understanding Data Distribution
contentHtml:
Quantiles and percentiles are fundamental concepts in descriptive statistics that help us understand the distribution of data.

A quantile is a value that divides the dataset into equal parts, while a percentile is a specific percentage point (e.g., 25th or 75th percentile). Quartiles, being the 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles, are particularly useful for summarizing datasets.
intuition: Think of quantiles as 'dividing lines' that help us understand where most of the data lies.
visualDescription: A box plot with quartiles, median, and outliers would be a helpful visual representation.
commonMistakes: Not understanding the difference between quantiles and percentiles
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, quantiles can help identify anomalies or outliers in datasets.
